media_caption: Tinguian men playing bamboo guitars
text_description: Bamboo instruments such as vertical flutes, paired-string bamboo drum, polychordal zithers, and bamboo tubes spread to the islands.
article_title: Tinguian men playing bamboo guitars

media_caption: Different types of blowing holes for flutes
text_description: Placement of midhole and corresponding stops in vertical bamboo flutes and tuning in polychordal zithers is invented.
article_title: Different types of blowing holes for flutes

media_caption: Flat gong gangsa, left, common among Northern Philippine peoples, and bossed gongs babandil  and agong, middle and right, common among Southern Philippine peoples
text_description: Flat gongs are shipped to the Philippine Islands, as evidenced by the first recorded shipwreck containing flat gongs in Tanjung Simpan, north Borneo bound for the Philippines. As late as 1600s, Chinese gongs (tam-tam and pum-piang) continue to be sold in the islands.
article_title: Flat gong gangsa, left, common among Northern Philippine peoples, and bossed gongs babandil  and agong, middle and right, common among Southern Philippine peoples

media_caption: Flat gong gangsa, left, common among Northern Philippine peoples, and bossed gongs babandil  and agong, middle and right, common among Southern Philippine peoples
text_description: Bossed gongs, cymbals, and bells are in use, as evidenced in balanghai boat excavations in Butuan, Mindanao.
article_title: Flat gong gangsa, left, common among Northern Philippine peoples, and bossed gongs babandil  and agong, middle and right, common among Southern Philippine peoples

media_caption: Original devotional music composed for the Dominican santuario  of San Juan del Monte in the second half of the 17th century
text_description: A collection of 18 prayers and songs (preserved in the Dominican santuario of San Juan del Monte) is made, one composition of which is “Letra en Tagalo[g].” This is the earliest extant transcultural music composition in the Philippines, combining Tagalog words with European melody.
article_title: Original devotional music composed for the Dominican santuario  of San Juan del Monte in the second half of the 17th century

media_caption: Juan S. Hernandez conducting the premiere performance of his Piano Concerto in D Minor with daughter Carmencita on the piano, ca 1950

media_caption: Philippine Constabulary band at the St Louis World’s Fair, USA, 1904
text_description: The Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band wins second prize in the St Louis Exposition. Also in the exposition are Jose Estella’s pieces, Diego Perez’s “Recuerdos,” traditional music from indigenous groups, and local music inventions such as Pio Trinidad’s first piano of Filipino manufacture, featuring Trinidad’s tremolofon device and Jose Canseco’s “tonopsis mecanica.” All win industry awards.

media_caption: Sheet music cover of “¡Amor! A Song of Love” dedicated to Jovita Fuentes, then treasurer of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, ca 1920

article_title: Sheet music cover of “¡Amor! A Song of Love” dedicated to Jovita Fuentes, then treasurer of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, ca 1920

media_caption: Sheet music cover of “Ang Maya,” 1905

media_caption: Philippine Constabulary Band performance, Manila, 1946
text_description: The PC Band returns to the USA to play in the inauguration of William Taft as president of the USA. The group also tours with sensational concerts in Boston, New York, Chicago, Washington, D.C. and San Francisco.

media_caption: Reformist writer Jose Rizal
text_description: The June issue of the Cultura Filipina lists 68 compositions between 1899 and 1910, which are dedicated to Jose Rizal or based on his works.
article_title: Reformist writer Jose Rizal

media_caption: The Manila Symphony Orchestra, 2014
text_description: The Monday Musical Club, an organization of US Army officers and soldiers, organizes the Manila Symphony Orchestra (not to be confused with that founded by Alexander Lippay in 1922).
article_title: The Manila Symphony Orchestra, 2014

media_caption: Progressive Music Series, an anthology of Filipino folk songs, used as educational material during the American period
text_description: Norberto Romualdez (1875-1941), through Horatio Parker and Silver Burdett Company, compiles arranged Philippine music for The Philippine Progressive Series, which is used as a music textbook in public schools thereafter.
article_title: Progressive Music Series, an anthology of Filipino folk songs, used as educational material during the American period

media_caption: UP Symphony Orchestra rehearsal conducted by Ramon Tapales, University of the Philippines, Quezon City, 1964
media_credit: UP College of Music Library Collection
text_description: After years of proposing bills in the Philippine Assembly, Senator Joaquin Luna (b. 1874) succeeds in getting passed into law (1915) the bill creating the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, with support by first Filipino president of UP Ignacio Villamor (1863-1933) and with guitarist-scientist Fernando Canon (1860-1938) as secretary of the conservatory.
article_title: UP Symphony Orchestra rehearsal conducted by Ramon Tapales, University of the Philippines, Quezon City, 1964

media_caption: Invitation for the sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid to be performed at the Teatro Zorrilla on Azcarraga,  now Claro M. Recto Avenue, in Manila, 1919
text_description: The sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid by Hermogenes Ilagan (1873–1943) is first staged, with music by Leon Ignacio (1882–1967). Because of its success, it is adapted into a silent film of the same title in 1919, becoming the first Philippine-produced film.
article_title: Invitation for the sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid to be performed at the Teatro Zorrilla on Azcarraga,  now Claro M. Recto Avenue, in Manila, 1919

media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
text_description: Francisco Santiago (1889-1947) composes “Anak ng Dalita,” which is considered the first art song kundiman, to be followed by Bonifacio Abdon’s “Kundiman” and Nicanor Abelardo’s “Kung Hindi Man” in 1920.
article_title: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago

media_caption: Epifanio de los Santos, notable Filipino writer in Spanish
text_description: Epifanio de los Santos (1871–1928) publishes “Folk-Lore Musical de Filipinas” in El Debate.
article_title: Epifanio de los Santos, notable Filipino writer in Spanish

media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
text_description: Francisco Santiago publishes arrangements of Filipino Folk Songs such as “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut) and “Leron-leron Sinta,” collected by Emilia S. Cavan.
article_title: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago

media_caption: Original string quartet of the Manila Chamber Music Society composed of, left to right,  Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Avellana, Felipe Marin, and Jose Carrion
text_description: The Manila Chamber Music Society is founded, with Bonifacio Abdon as primary mover.
article_title: Original string quartet of the Manila Chamber Music Society composed of, left to right,  Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Avellana, Felipe Marin, and Jose Carrion

media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
text_description: Francisco Santiago presents his Piano Concerto in B-flat minor as a requirement for his doctorate of music degree at the Chicago Musical College. Santiago is the first Filipino to hold a doctoral degree in music, major in music composition.
article_title: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago

media_caption: KZIB broadcasting staff, 1938
media_credit: Photo courtesy of National Economic Protectionism Association
text_description: Isaac Beck’s radio station KZIB begins broadcast of Filipino songs rendered by Naty Arellano and other Columbia artists.
article_title: KZIB broadcasting staff, 1938

media_caption: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010
text_description: The Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) is founded by Alexander Lippay (1892-1939). One of the oldest existing symphonic orchestras in Asia, it introduces new concert programming, changing the way the urban audiences listen to conservatory music.
article_title: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010

media_caption: Luva Adameit, middle, teacher of classical ballet to the first generation of Filipino dancers and choreographers, ca 1922
text_description: Luva Adameit (1895-1948), Polish dancer, arrives in Manila, where she creates stylized orientalist ballets on local themes such as “Planting Rice” and the folk dance “Cariñosa.” This pioneering stance would continue with Anita Kane’s ballet “Mariang Makiling” in 1939, with music by Ramon Tapales.
article_title: Luva Adameit, middle, teacher of classical ballet to the first generation of Filipino dancers and choreographers, ca 1922

media_caption: Notable Filipino opera singers, from left, Jovita Fuentes, Isang Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, and Conching Rosal
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Jovita Fuentes (1895-1978) records “Ay Kalisud” (Ah, Misery) and other Filipino folk songs for Odeon Records in Germany.
article_title: Notable Filipino opera singers, from left, Jovita Fuentes, Isang Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, and Conching Rosal

media_caption: National Artists for music, Atang de la Rama, 1987
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Constancio de Guzman (1903-1982) composes the nationalist kundiman “Bayan Ko” (My Country) with lyrics by Jose Corazon de Jesus (1896-1932). De Guzman was a student of Abelardo in UP. Atang de la Rama (1905-1991) popularizes the song.
article_title: National Artists for music, Atang de la Rama, 1987

media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
text_description: Francisco Santiago wins two composition contests “Cristo Rey” and “Himno del Congreso Eucaristico.”
article_title: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago

media_caption: Sheet music cover of “Sa Kabukiran,” 1939
text_description: Manuel Velez (1894-1959) composes a balitaw romansada (composed balitaw) “Sa Kabukiran” in 1928.
article_title: Sheet music cover of “Sa Kabukiran,” 1939

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, one of the announcers on  KZRC-Voice of Freedom
text_description: Radio Corporation of the Philippines opens radio station KZRC (now DYRC), the oldest radio station in Cebu, which later showcases the music of local composers Thomas Villaflor (b. 1900), Domingo Lopez (1912-1981), Ben Zubiri (1911-1969), and others.
article_title: Carlos P. Romulo, one of the announcers on  KZRC-Voice of Freedom

media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
text_description: Francisco Santiago assumes his post as the first Filipino director of the UP Conservatory of Music.
article_title: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago

media_caption: Prewar Manila Metropolitan Theater facade
text_description: Metropolitan Theater in Plaza Lawton is inaugurated, with Jose Estella’s opera “Lakambini.” It will be the site of major music events until WWII when it is destroyed.
article_title: Prewar Manila Metropolitan Theater facade

media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonio J. Molina, awarded in 1973
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Antonio Molina (1894-1980) pioneers a choral cycle using Filipino folk songs in his First Choral Cycle.
article_title: National Artists for music, Antonio J. Molina, awarded in 1973

media_caption: Scene from CCP’s La Traviata, 1992, set in late 19th century Manila
text_description: Victorino Carrion (voice teacher), Bonifacio Abdon (conductor), and Juan Javier (impresario) revive the opera by staging Aida (in February); La Traviata (May); Cavelleria Rusticana (August); and Lucia di Lammermoor (September).
article_title: Scene from CCP’s La Traviata, 1992, set in late 19th century Manila

media_caption: Mila del Sol singing with the SSS Trio or Silos Sisters in  Giliw Ko, 1939, with music by Juan Silos Jr and Ariston Avelino
text_description: Sarsuwela films such as Bituing Marikit (1937), Nasaan Ka Irog (1937), Giliw Ko (1939), Pakiusap (1940), are made.
article_title: Mila del Sol singing with the SSS Trio or Silos Sisters in  Giliw Ko, 1939, with music by Juan Silos Jr and Ariston Avelino

media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino), in striped skirt, learning a Kalinga dance, 1962; and, previous, Philippine National Dances, her anthology of indigenous and folk dances documented from all over the archipelago
text_description: Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino) collaborates with Ramon Tolentino and Antonino Buenaventura in collecting folk dances.
article_title: Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino), in striped skirt, learning a Kalinga dance, 1962; and, previous, Philippine National Dances, her anthology of indigenous and folk dances documented from all over the archipelago

media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card,  signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
media_credit: Photo courtesy of Amateur Radio Station
text_description: Juan Silos Jr (1898-1988) introduces the Silos Sisters in KZRM’s radio program Manila Radiolites in 1934-35.
article_title: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card,  signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ramon Tapales in 1992
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: In 1935, Ramon Tapales (1906-1995) founds the Philippine Cultural Concert Society Symphony Orchestra, which exists until 1939.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ramon Tapales in 1992

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Mike Velarde, 1986
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Miguel Velarde (1913-1986) composes a love song in danza style “Dahil sa Iyo.”
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Mike Velarde, 1986

media_caption: Bodabil rehearsal, with musicians at orchestra pit, ca 1950
text_description: Stage shows, the expanded bodabil, rises to popularity, showcasing musical, radio, and film artists, and directed by film directors.
article_title: Bodabil rehearsal, with musicians at orchestra pit, ca 1950

media_caption: UST Symphony Orchestra performing at the 2015 Pasinaya Arts Festival, CCP, Manila
text_description: UST’s conservatory of music is founded with Manuel de Cuerva as its first director and Rev Gregorio Garcia OP as regent.
article_title: UST Symphony Orchestra performing at the 2015 Pasinaya Arts Festival, CCP, Manila

media_caption: Manila Cathedral Choir conducted by Fr John Van de Steen, CICM, 1966
text_description: Belgian priest John van de Steen, CICM arrives in Manila, organizing church choirs and directing their musical activities until his death in 1987.
article_title: Manila Cathedral Choir conducted by Fr John Van de Steen, CICM, 1966

media_caption: Priscilla, the “Kolynos” girl, with pianists Rafael Artigas, left, and Ariston Avelino
text_description: For Sampaguita musicals, Tirso Cruz composes for Isang Sulyap Mo, Tita (1953, starring Pancho Magalona and Tita Duran) and Constancio de Guzman, Maalaala Mo Kaya (1954, starring Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa); for LVN, Juan Silos, Jr composes for Batangueña (1953) and Waray Waray (1954), both films starring Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa; for Premiere, Santiago Suarez composes for Bakya Mo Neneng (1947, starring Rosa del Rosario and Leopoldo Salcedo).
article_title: Priscilla, the “Kolynos” girl, with pianists Rafael Artigas, left, and Ariston Avelino

media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Antonino Buenaventura premieres Mindanao Sketches after his decade-long research on Manobo music in connection with a project on Folk Songs and Dances at the University of the Philippines (UP).
article_title: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988

media_caption: Balitaw performed in Guadalupe, Cebu, 1990
text_description: DYRC radio station in Cebu promotes Cebuano balitaw with singer pair Antonio Bohol and Josefina Bacalso, following the fame of prewar pair Pedro Alfafara and Nicolasa Caniban.
article_title: Balitaw performed in Guadalupe, Cebu, 1990

media_caption: Popular radio performer Cecil Lloyd
text_description: Cecil Lloyd puts up one of the first known Filipino-owned recording companies, the Philippine Recording system (PRS).
article_title: Popular radio performer Cecil Lloyd

media_caption: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Lucio San Pedro composes his only concerto, Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, which utilizes the Igorot tune, “Naantoay,” in its final movement.
article_title: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991

media_caption: National Artists for music, Levi Celerio, 1997
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Levi Celerio writes the lyrics for Lucio D. San Pedro’s composition “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan”.
article_title: National Artists for music, Levi Celerio, 1997

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ramon Tapales, 1992
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Ramon Tapales (1906-1995) publishes the series Singing and Growing for Primary Grades, which discusses compositions and folk songs, with some sample songs from the United States and various European countries.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ramon Tapales, 1992

media_caption: Artists singing patriotic songs during the 1986 EDSA Revolt
text_description: Mambo Magsaysay, Magsaysay’s campaign song fills the airwaves. It will be used as the station ID of Radyo Bandido during the February 1986 EDSA Revolt.
article_title: Artists singing patriotic songs during the 1986 EDSA Revolt

media_caption: Renowned Filipino composers, from left, Lucrecia Kasilag, Rodolfo Cornejo, Lucino Sacramento, Antonio Molina, Eliseo Pajaro,  Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Lucio San Pedro, 1956
text_description: Corazon Maceda and Crispina Garcia publish Philippine Choruses for All Occasions, a compilation of choral arrangements of folk songs by Lucio San Pedro, Francisco Santiago, Francisco Buencamino, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Antonio Molina, and Corazon Maceda.
article_title: Renowned Filipino composers, from left, Lucrecia Kasilag, Rodolfo Cornejo, Lucino Sacramento, Antonio Molina, Eliseo Pajaro,  Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Lucio San Pedro, 1956

media_caption: National Artists for music, Felipe Padilla  de Leon, 1997
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: To eliminate the practice called tambakan, unite local bands in the country, and promote good band music, the Pambansang Samahan ng Mga Banda sa Pilipinas (National Band Association of the Philippines) or PASAMBAP is organized by Felipe Padilla De Leon.
article_title: National Artists for music, Felipe Padilla  de Leon, 1997

media_caption: Jazz band with Lito Molina on the alto sax, left, Angel Peña on the upright bass, behind, and Emil Mijares at the piano, among others, ca 1965
text_description: Upsilon Sigma Phi Fraternity in UP begins its series of “experimental jazz,” which features jazz that appropriate folk songs such as Narding Aristorenas’s “Planting Rice” and Angel Peña’s “Bagbagtulambing.”
article_title: Jazz band with Lito Molina on the alto sax, left, Angel Peña on the upright bass, behind, and Emil Mijares at the piano, among others, ca 1965

media_caption: Former first lady Luz B. Magsaysay, second from right, with members of the Music Promotion Foundation  of the Philippines, left to right, Jose Lauchengco, Lucrecia Kasilag, and chair Jovita Fuentes, 1959
text_description: Under the Republic Act No. 1370, the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP) is created to function, among others, as a scholarship-granting agency for poor but talented students.
article_title: Former first lady Luz B. Magsaysay, second from right, with members of the Music Promotion Foundation  of the Philippines, left to right, Jose Lauchengco, Lucrecia Kasilag, and chair Jovita Fuentes, 1959

media_caption: Members of the League of Filipino Composers, from left, Francisco Feliciano, Alfredo Buenaventura, Lucrecia Kasilag,  Ramon Santos, Antonino Buenaventura, Josefino Toledo, and Restituto Umali, ca 1980
text_description: The League of Filipino Composers is founded to stress the importance of creating a body of Filipino art music in the conservatory tradition.
article_title: Members of the League of Filipino Composers, from left, Francisco Feliciano, Alfredo Buenaventura, Lucrecia Kasilag,  Ramon Santos, Antonino Buenaventura, Josefino Toledo, and Restituto Umali, ca 1980

media_caption: Scene from Carmen, 1956
text_description: Bizet’s opera Carmen is translated into Tagalog and staged successfully by the Manila Symphony Society in the FEU Auditorium in 1956.
article_title: Scene from Carmen, 1956

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Nena del Rosario, 1997
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Nena del Rosario, piano prodigy, earns an artist diploma in Curtis Institute.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Nena del Rosario, 1997

media_caption: A collection of Visayan folk songs, published by Silliman Music Foundation Inc in 1957
text_description: Priscilla Magdamo publishes the multi-volume Philippine Folk Songs: Songs of the Visayas, through the Silliman Music Foundation, Inc., after her field work in Banga, Aklan in 1956.
article_title: A collection of Visayan folk songs, published by Silliman Music Foundation Inc in 1957

media_caption: Scene from Noli Me Tangere, 1987
text_description: Felipe Padilla de Leon’s opera Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), with libretto by Guillermo Tolentino (1890 – 1976), is staged.
article_title: Scene from Noli Me Tangere, 1987

media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Antonino Buenaventura receives the Republic Cultural Heritage award.
article_title: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988

media_caption: Dr Ramon P. Santos conducting an orchestra and choir at the Nicanor Abelardo Hall Auditorium of  the University of the Philippines in Diliman, Quezon City
text_description: The Abelardo Hall Auditorium of the UP Conservatory of Music is built to serve as main venue for music concerts in the Quezon City area.
article_title: Dr Ramon P. Santos conducting an orchestra and choir at the Nicanor Abelardo Hall Auditorium of  the University of the Philippines in Diliman, Quezon City

media_caption: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Lucio D. San Pedro is awarded the Republic Cultural Heritage for his symphonic poem Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race).
article_title: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991

media_caption: enowned Filipino composers, from left, Lucrecia Kasilag, Rodolfo Cornejo, Lucino Sacramento, Antonio Molina, Eliseo Pajaro,  Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Lucio San Pedro, 1956
text_description: The Rizal Centennial Commission produces Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seed of Freedom) by Eliseo Pajaro, with Ricardo Pascual as librettist. It is the first Filipino opera written in the 20th-century neoclassical idiom.
article_title: enowned Filipino composers, from left, Lucrecia Kasilag, Rodolfo Cornejo, Lucino Sacramento, Antonio Molina, Eliseo Pajaro,  Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Lucio San Pedro, 1956

media_caption: The Philippine Madrigal Singers at their Trionfo concert, CCP, Manila, 2016
text_description: The UP Madrigal Singers, later known as the Philippine Madrigal Singers, is founded by Andrea O. Veneracion (1928-2013).
article_title: The Philippine Madrigal Singers at their Trionfo concert, CCP, Manila, 2016

media_caption: Pangkat Kawayan at Aurora A. Quezon Elementary School, ca 1960
text_description: Victor Toledo organizes Pangkat Kawayan, which consists of grade school children playing different types of bamboo instruments (flutes, marimba, clappers, angklung, bumbong) as an attempt to revive the musikong bumbong, an ensemble of bamboo-made band instruments.
article_title: Pangkat Kawayan at Aurora A. Quezon Elementary School, ca 1960

media_caption: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Rosalina Abejo, RVM (1922-1991) premieres the first of only two oratorios in Philippine choral literature, Ang Pagtutubos (The Salvation). The other is Lucio San Pedro’s The Redeemer, 1990.
article_title: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991

media_caption: Album cover of Jose Maceda: Gongs and Bamboos, 2001, which includes “Pagsamba”
text_description: Jose Maceda premieres Pagsamba.
article_title: Album cover of Jose Maceda: Gongs and Bamboos, 2001, which includes “Pagsamba”

media_caption: Aga Mayo Butocan at the Chants, Ragas & Rhythms  for PEACE, 2017
text_description: Aga Mayo Butocan, Maguindanaon kulintang player, begins teaching at the University of the Philippines’ Asian music program.
article_title: Aga Mayo Butocan at the Chants, Ragas & Rhythms  for PEACE, 2017

media_caption: Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Mir-i-nisa, Dance Theater Philippines, choreographed by Julie Borromeo and Tita Radaic, CCP, Manila, 1969
text_description: The Cultural Center of the Philippines is inaugurated with Lurecia Kasilag’s music in the stage drama Golden Salakot: Isang Dularawan and Eliseo Pajaro’s ballet Mir-i-nisa.
article_title: Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Mir-i-nisa, Dance Theater Philippines, choreographed by Julie Borromeo and Tita Radaic, CCP, Manila, 1969

media_caption: Notable Filipino opera singers, from left, Jovita Fuentes, Isang Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, and Conching Rosal
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Dalisay Aldaba establishes the Opera Guild of the Philippines; their staging of Puccini’s Madame Butterfly in 1973 becomes famous.
article_title: Notable Filipino opera singers, from left, Jovita Fuentes, Isang Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, and Conching Rosal

media_caption: National Artist for Theater Daisy Hontiveros- Avellana awarded in 1999
text_description: Daisy Avellana directs the revival of Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat, with music by Fulgencio Tolentino and others at the Cultural Center of the Philippines; Constancio de Guzman’s “Bayan Ko” is added to the original music.
article_title: National Artist for Theater Daisy Hontiveros- Avellana awarded in 1999

media_caption: Inang Laya performance, ca 1980
text_description: The tradition of protest songs such as “Makibaka,” “Awit ng Pakikibaka,” “Ang Paglaban,” and rewritten “Sulong ng Bayan” re-emerges. Meanwhile, songs by activist songwriters such as Heber Bartolome, Jess Santiago, Patatag, Inang Laya find an enthusiastic audience.
article_title: Inang Laya performance, ca 1980

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Gilopez and Corazon Kabayao, 2008
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: The Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation honors the violinist Gilopez Kabayao.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Gilopez and Corazon Kabayao, 2008

media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonio J. Molina, awarded in 1973
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Antonio J. Molina (1894-1980) is named National Artist for Music.
article_title: National Artists for music, Antonio J. Molina, awarded in 1973

media_caption: Chorale competing at the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), 1989
text_description: The National Music Competition for Young Artists, initially based in CCP, is organized in 1973 to discover young artists in the fields of choral singing, piano, other music instruments, chamber music, family ensemble, and indigenous music.
article_title: Chorale competing at the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), 1989

media_caption: Alice Reyes's Carmina Burana, with live accompaniment by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and a choir of 200 voices, CCP, Manila, 1975
text_description: In 1973, the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra is founded by Luis Valencia (1913-1982); it is renamed Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) with Oscar Yatco (1931-2014) as music director in 1982.
article_title: Alice Reyes's Carmina Burana, with live accompaniment by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and a choir of 200 voices, CCP, Manila, 1975

media_caption: Members of the Juan de la Cruz Band, from left, Wally Gonzalez, Mike Hanopol,  and Pepe Smith, ca 1970, and one of their records, opposite page
text_description: The Juan de la Cruz Band, the icon of Pinoy Rock, produces their most famous song “Himig Natin,” first recorded in 1968 but released in 1973. This song is considered the first truly Filipino rock.
article_title: Members of the Juan de la Cruz Band, from left, Wally Gonzalez, Mike Hanopol,  and Pepe Smith, ca 1970, and one of their records, opposite page

media_caption: Vinyl record covers of Hotdog’s Unang Kagat, 1974, Cinderella’s Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy, 1975, and Mike Hanopol’s Buhay Musikero, 1977
media_credit: Villar Records, Viva Records, and Jem Recording
text_description: The band Hotdog records their 1973 hit “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You are the Miss Universe in My Life), the genre of which will later on assume the name Manila Sound.
article_title: Vinyl record covers of Hotdog’s Unang Kagat, 1974, Cinderella’s Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy, 1975, and Mike Hanopol’s Buhay Musikero, 1977

media_caption: Las Piñas Bamboo Festival, 2015
text_description: The Las Piñas Bamboo Organ built by Fr. Cera and his assistants is restored and the Bamboo Organ Festival is organized.
article_title: Las Piñas Bamboo Festival, 2015

media_caption: Scene from Bato sa Buhangin, 1976, starring Vilma Santos and Fernando Poe Jr
text_description: Ernani Cuenco (1936-1988) composes the music of Bato sa Buhangin (Pebble in the Sand) which becomes the theme song of the movie of the same title.
article_title: Scene from Bato sa Buhangin, 1976, starring Vilma Santos and Fernando Poe Jr

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ryan Cayabyab, 2004
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Ryan Cayabyab (b. 1954) pioneers in neo-ethnic fusion music that integrates indigenous singkil rhythm in the solo CD Roots to Routes.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ryan Cayabyab, 2004

media_caption: Vinyl record cover of Freddie Aguilar’s Anak, 1977
text_description: The first Metro Manila Popular Music Festival or Metropop is held at the Folk Arts Theater, with Ryan Cayabyab’s “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” as grand prize winner. Freddie Aguilar’s “Anak” (Child) will sell at an unprecedented 30,000 copies and will be translated into several foreign languages, making it the most successful music industry product in Philippine history.
article_title: Vinyl record cover of Freddie Aguilar’s Anak, 1977

media_caption: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010
text_description: Teodoro Valencia begins the Channel 4 program of classical music dubbed Concert at the Park, rendered by the Metro Manila Symphony Orchestra under conductor Regalado Jose with Tina Monzon-Palma as host.
article_title: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010

media_caption: Sayaw sa Bangko by Philippine High School for the Arts's Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw, Pindayog, Rizal Park, Manila, 2017
media_credit: Hedrik 'Bhojeck' Sibal, photo courtesy of PHSA
text_description: The Philippine High School for the Arts in Makiling, Los Banos, is opened with offerings in visual and performing arts.
article_title: Sayaw sa Bangko by Philippine High School for the Arts's Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw, Pindayog, Rizal Park, Manila, 2017

media_caption: Rama, Hari, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2012
text_description: Ryan Cayabyab collaborates with Alice Reyes and Bienvenido Lumbera in producing the highly successful ballet Rama Hari staged in CCP by Ballet Philippines.
article_title: Rama, Hari, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2012

media_caption: Dinagyang Festival, Iloilo City, 2017
text_description: Local Government of Cebu secularizes the devotional dance sinulog by initiating street dancing as part of the feast of Santo Niño. Parallel initiatives in the secularization of sacred expressions, now linked to tourism, is manifest in Aklan’s Ati-Atihan and Ilo-ilo’s Dinagyang. Secular street dancing is demonstrated in Davao’s Kadayawan festival and Baguio City Panagbenga Festival.
article_title: Dinagyang Festival, Iloilo City, 2017

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ryan Cayabyab, 2004
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Ryan Cayabyab’s LP “One” is released. It is considered a landmark project for its one-man multitrack a cappella work featuring 16 voices.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ryan Cayabyab, 2004

media_caption: Pianist Cecile Licad performing in Tarleton, Texas, 2015
media_credit: Photo courtesy of Tarleton State University
text_description: Cecile Licad wins the Leventritt Award.
article_title: Pianist Cecile Licad performing in Tarleton, Texas, 2015

media_caption: Inang Laya performance, ca 1980
text_description: Inang Laya, a singing duo composed of Becky Demetillo-Abraham and Karina Constantino-David, releases its first album Pagpupuyos, which contains nationalist songs from the underground resistance movement, also popularized in street rallies from 1983 to 1986.
article_title: Inang Laya performance, ca 1980

media_caption: Album covers of Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas, 1986; Gary Valenciano’s Moving Thoughts, 1988; and Joey Ayala’s Panganay ng Umaga, 1991
text_description: Joey Ayala (b. 1956) records his first album on cassette Panganay ng Umaga, which will be re-recorded and re-released in 1989 and in 1991 as “neo-ethnic” fusion music.
article_title: Album covers of Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas, 1986; Gary Valenciano’s Moving Thoughts, 1988; and Joey Ayala’s Panganay ng Umaga, 1991

media_caption: Popular radio performer Cecil Lloyd
text_description: Popular Music Foundation initiates the music-industry awards known as the Cecil Awards. Named after Cecil Lloyd, the “Filipino Mystery Singer,” it honors the country’s best recording artists, encourages musicians, and raises artistic standards in the music industry.
article_title: Popular radio performer Cecil Lloyd

media_caption: Folk musician Freddie Aguilar performing in Tondo, Manila, 1983
text_description: Freddie Aguilar’s recording of de Guzman’s “Bayan Ko” becomes the “second national anthem” as people’s sentiment gains momentum against the Marcos dictatorship.
article_title: Folk musician Freddie Aguilar performing in Tondo, Manila, 1983

media_caption: National Artists for music, Francisco Feliciano, 2014
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: The magnum opus of Francisco Feliciano (1941-2014), the opera ballet La Loba Negra, is staged in CCP with Fides Cuyugan-Asencio (b. 1931) as the main character.
article_title: National Artists for music, Francisco Feliciano, 2014

media_caption: PETA’s Kalayaan, an anti-Marcos street play, with protest leaders seated at far right, from right, Lorenzo Tañada, Corazon C. Aquino, Diosdado Macapagal, and Armando Malay, Post Office Building Manila, 1983
media_credit: William Tan, photo courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection
text_description: The first Makiisa Festival is held showcasing different anti-Marcos protests in the fields of visual, performing, literary, film, and broadcast arts.
article_title: PETA’s Kalayaan, an anti-Marcos street play, with protest leaders seated at far right, from right, Lorenzo Tañada, Corazon C. Aquino, Diosdado Macapagal, and Armando Malay, Post Office Building Manila, 1983

media_caption: The Sacred Works of Ryan Cayabyab cover, 2004
media_credit: The San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts
text_description: Esteban Villaruz, aka Basilio (b. 1940), choreographs Cayabyab’s Misa, featuring the UP Concert Chorus and the UP Dance Company.
article_title: The Sacred Works of Ryan Cayabyab cover, 2004

media_caption: Sr Mary Placid Abejo, OSB with children from the PREDIS program
media_credit: Sr Baptista Battig Music Foundation, Inc
text_description: Basilio Manalo (1927-2008) and Sr Mary Placid (b. 1934) of St Scholastica’s School of Music organize PREDIS (Philippine Research for Developing Instrumental Soloists), which is a string program for young music learners.
article_title: Sr Mary Placid Abejo, OSB with children from the PREDIS program

media_caption: The Dawn performing their hit song “Iisang Bangka,” San Juan City, 2016
text_description: Executive Order 255 takes effect on Jul 25, requiring radio stations to play at least four original Pilipino music (OPM) pieces every hour.
article_title: The Dawn performing their hit song “Iisang Bangka,” San Juan City, 2016

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Dalagang Bukid, featuring Noemi Manikan-Gomez, center, CCP, Manila, 1987
text_description: Honorata “Atang” de la Rama is named National Artist for Theater and Music. In her honor, the sarsuwela “Dalagang Bukid” is re-staged as the inaugural presentation of CCP’s new resident company Tanghalang Pilipino.
article_title: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Dalagang Bukid, featuring Noemi Manikan-Gomez, center, CCP, Manila, 1987

media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988

media_caption: Album cover of Regine Velasquez’s Nineteen ‘90, 1990,  which includes “Narito Ako”
text_description: Regine Velazquez (b. 1970) receives the moniker “Asia’s Songbird” after winning the Asia Pacific Singing Contest. Two years later, she conquers Carnegie Hall with a highly successful concert.
article_title: Album cover of Regine Velasquez’s Nineteen ‘90, 1990,  which includes “Narito Ako”

media_caption: The Philippine Madrigal Singers at their Trionfo concert, CCP, Manila, 2016

article_title: The Philippine Madrigal Singers at their Trionfo concert, CCP, Manila, 2016

media_caption: Balitaw performed in Guadalupe, Cebu, 1990

article_title: Balitaw performed in Guadalupe, Cebu, 1990

media_caption: Scene from CCP’s La Traviata, 1992, set in late 19th century Manila
text_description: CCP produces Rolando Tinio’s Tagalog adaptations of La Traviata and La Boheme.
article_title: Scene from CCP’s La Traviata, 1992, set in late 19th century Manila

media_caption: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991

media_caption: Agnes Locsin's Encantada, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1992

media_caption: Album cover of  Francis Magalona’s Yo!, 1990,  which includes “Mga Kababayan Ko”
text_description: Francis M. releases Rap is Francis M, which scrutinizes the ailments of Philippine society, such as colonial mentality, drug addiction, and government corruption.
article_title: Album cover of  Francis Magalona’s Yo!, 1990,  which includes “Mga Kababayan Ko”

media_caption: 1993 Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) awardees: Samaon Sulaiman, left, and Masino Intaray

media_caption: Album cover of Eraserheads’ Ultraelectromagneticpop!,  1989, which includes “Ligaya”
text_description: The band Eraserheads debuts its studio album Ultraelectromagneticpop!, trending a revival of Original Pilipino Music, especially the various types of alternative music.
article_title: Album cover of Eraserheads’ Ultraelectromagneticpop!,  1989, which includes “Ligaya”

media_caption: The original members of Rivermaya, from left, Nathan Azarcon, Mark Escueta, Rico Blanco, and Bamboo Mañalac, ca 1990

article_title: The original members of Rivermaya, from left, Nathan Azarcon, Mark Escueta, Rico Blanco, and Bamboo Mañalac, ca 1990

media_caption: vCathedral of Cebu organ constructed by Cealwyn Tagle  and Edgar Montiano
text_description: Cealwyn Tagle and Edgar Montiano construct a pipe organ for the St. Joseph’s Academy Auditorium, the start of their successive building and restoration of pipe organs under the company, Diego Cera Builders Inc.
article_title: vCathedral of Cebu organ constructed by Cealwyn Tagle  and Edgar Montiano

media_caption: The Philippine Madrigal Singers at their Trionfo concert, CCP, Manila, 2016

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, ides Cuyugan-Asensio, 2015

article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, ides Cuyugan-Asensio, 2015

media_caption: Musical Theater Philippines’s Ang Larawan: The Musical, featuring Celeste Legaspi and Rachel Alejandro as Candida and Paula, respectively, both in Nazarene red, CCP, Manila, 1997
text_description: Musical Theater Philippines stages Larawan based on Nick Joaquin’s play A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, with lyrics by Rolando Tinio and music by Ryan Cayabyab. It is made into a movie in 2017.
article_title: Musical Theater Philippines’s Ang Larawan: The Musical, featuring Celeste Legaspi and Rachel Alejandro as Candida and Paula, respectively, both in Nazarene red, CCP, Manila, 1997

media_caption: Ricky Davao in Palasyo ni Valentin, College of Saint Benilde, 2015
text_description: Four new sarsuwela win the National Sarsuwela Competition: Mario O’Hara’s “Palasyo ni Valentin,” with music by Minda Azarcon; George de Jesus III’s “Paglayang Minamahal,” with music by Jeffrey Hernandez; Bienvenido Lumbera’s “Hibik ng Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw,” with music by Lucien Letaba; and Melba Camagay’s “Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang,” with music by Lucio San Pedro.
article_title: Ricky Davao in Palasyo ni Valentin, College of Saint Benilde, 2015

media_caption: Book cover of Gongs & Bamboo, 1998
text_description: José Maceda publishes his landmark book Gongs and Bamboo, which synthesizes the decades-old cultural mapping of indigenous music instruments in the country.
article_title: Book cover of Gongs & Bamboo, 1998

media_caption: Members of the League of Filipino Composers, from left, Francisco Feliciano, Alfredo Buenaventura, Lucrecia Kasilag,  Ramon Santos, Antonino Buenaventura, Josefino Toledo, and Restituto Umali, ca 1980
text_description: Gala concerts dubbed “Alay sa Sandaang Taon” at the CCP on Jun 13-14 feature commissioned works by Ramon Santos, Lucrecia Kasilag, Jeffrey Ching and Josefino Toledo.
article_title: Members of the League of Filipino Composers, from left, Francisco Feliciano, Alfredo Buenaventura, Lucrecia Kasilag,  Ramon Santos, Antonino Buenaventura, Josefino Toledo, and Restituto Umali, ca 1980

media_caption: National Artists for music, Ernani Cuenco, 1999

article_title: National Artists for music, Ernani Cuenco, 1999

media_caption: 2000 Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) awardees, from left: Uwang Ahadas, Federico Caballero, and Alonzo Saclag
text_description: Uwang Ahadas, Frederico Caballero, and Alonzo Saclag receive the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) award
article_title: 2000 Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) awardees, from left: Uwang Ahadas, Federico Caballero, and Alonzo Saclag

media_caption: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010
text_description: Former concertmaster Basilio Manalo reorganizes Manila Symphony Orchestra, renaming it Manila Symphony Orchestra 2.
article_title: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010

media_caption: San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra performing under conductor Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Under the artistic direction of Ryan Cayabyab, the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts founds the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra and San Miguel Master Chorale in 2001. It exists until 2007, producing notable records of Filipino music.
article_title: San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra performing under conductor Ryan Cayabyab

media_caption: Francis M and Gloc-9 performing at a MYX anniversary concert, 2007
text_description: Rapper-songwriter Gloc-9 debuts with a studio self-titled album G9 released by Star Records.
article_title: Francis M and Gloc-9 performing at a MYX anniversary concert, 2007

media_caption: Sarah Geronimo performing in Cebu City, 2013
text_description: TV singing contests are revived with Search for a Star, 2003; Star in a Million, ABS-CBN 2003; Little Big Star, ABS-CBN, 2005-2007; Philippine Idol, TV5 and GMA Network, 2006-2008; Pinoy Idol, GMA Network, 2006; Pinoy Pop Superstar, GMA, 2006; and The Voice of the Philippines, ABS-CBN2013. Sarah Geronimo, Rachel Ann Go, and Christian Bautista are some of the winners in these contests.
article_title: Sarah Geronimo performing in Cebu City, 2013

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Himala The Musicale, CCP, Manila, 2003
text_description: Vincent de Jesus’s musical Himala is first staged by Tanghalang Pilipino in CCP.
article_title: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Himala The Musicale, CCP, Manila, 2003

media_caption: National Artists for music, Ramon P. Santos, 2014
media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: Ramon Santos initiates the International Rondalla Festival in Naga.
article_title: National Artists for music, Ramon P. Santos, 2014

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ryan Cayabyab, 2004
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: Ryan Cayabyab receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
article_title: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ryan Cayabyab, 2004

media_caption: Book cover of Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music, 2005
text_description: Ramon Santos’s book Tunugan: Essays on Filipino Music (UP Press) in published, which approaches the subject from a music critical standpoint.
article_title: Book cover of Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music, 2005

media_caption: FilHarmonika with conductor, Gerard Salonga, performing at the Insular Life Theater, Alabang, 2008
text_description: Global Studio Orchestra (GC4) or FILharmoniKa with conductor Gerard Salonga fulfills outsourcing needs of commercial recording and film scoring needs of the global market. Salonga will later move on to lead the ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra, also for the same goals.
article_title: FilHarmonika with conductor, Gerard Salonga, performing at the Insular Life Theater, Alabang, 2008

media_caption: Internet discovery Charice Pempengco on the cover of her self-titled EP, 2008
text_description: Charice Pempengco guests at the Ellen DeGeneres Show after the host sees her performances on YouTube. This is followed by invitations from Oprah Winfrey and a contract from the music producer David Foster.
article_title: Internet discovery Charice Pempengco on the cover of her self-titled EP, 2008
